article.title: The multiscale structural and mechanical effects of mouse supraspinatus muscle unloading on the mature enthesis
funding: National Institute of Health (NIH) R01 EB016422
National Institute of Health (NIH) R01 AR057836
National Space Biomedical Research Institute (NSBRI) NSBRI-RFA-13–01 Postdoctoral First Fellow Award
article.abstract: The musculoskeletal system is sensitive to its loading environment; this is of particular concern under conditions such as disuse, paralysis, and extended-duration space flight.

sections.introduction: The musculoskeletal system is sensitive to its loading environment. Mechanical forces are necessary to maintain tissue structure and composition capable of bearing loads.
sections.methods: Forty adult male CD-1 mice aged 30–34 weeks of age were separated into two groups: control and injected.
sections.results: Botox-induced unloading had only marginal effects on the load-deformation behavior of the enthesis.
sections.discussion: It is well known that the developing and adult musculoskeletal systems are sensitive to their mechanical environment.

technologies: scanning transmission electron microscopy-electron energy loss spectroscopy spectral imaging

technologies_detail.text: synchrotron nano-X-ray diffraction and X-ray fluorescence
scanning transmission electron microscopy-electron energy loss spectroscopy spectral imaging
technologies_detail.normalized: scanning transmission electron microscopy-electron energy loss spectroscopy spectral imaging

article.insights_summary: The musculoskeletal system is sensitive to its loading environment; this is of particular concern under conditions such as disuse, paralysis, and extended-duration space flight.
article.acknowledgments: This project was funded by National Institute of Health (NIH) R01 EB016422 and R01 AR057836.
